tooltips.campaign_type: Product launches typically pay 20% more than awareness campaigns
tooltips.partnership_duration: Longer partnerships = higher rates. A 1-year deal should pay 40% more
tooltips.exclusivity: If the brand asks you not to work with competitors, charge 30-50% more
tooltips.usage_rights: If they want to use your content in ads, charge 80-150% more

results_view.insights_summary: With an average rate of {{rate}}, you are positioned as a {{level}} influencer.
results_view.insights_summary_extra: You've earned an extra {{extra}} thanks to negotiation this month!
results_view.insights_empty: Start calculating your rates to unlock personalized insights for your negotiation strategy.
results_view.renewals_empty: No partnerships expiring in the next 7 days.
results_view.tip_1: Start at {{max}}, be ready to settle at {{avg}}
results_view.tip_2: Never go below {{min}} for this type of deal
results_view.tip_3_enterprise: Ask about long-term partnerships for better rates and exclusivity bonuses
results_view.tip_3_default: Highlight your engagement rate and audience quality during negotiations
results_view.leaving_on_table: You're potentially leaving {{amount}} on the table
results_view.cta_title: Want to know your EXACT rate?

tips.anchor: Never share your rate first. Ask for their budget to anchor the negotiation higher.
tips.usage: Charge +20-30% extra if the brand wants to run ads (Whitelisting) with your content.
tips.exclusivity: If they ask for exclusivity (no competitors), triple your rate for that period.
tips.package: Sell packages (3 videos) instead of one-offs to increase immediate revenue.
tips.lowball: Your last offer was low. Counter with your 'Fair Rate' and justify with your engagement stats.
tips.q4: It's Q4! Ad budgets are highest now. Add a 15-20% premium to all your quotes.
tips.jan: January is slow for ads. Focus on long-term partnerships rather than quick cash.
tips.yt_shorts: YouTube integrations pay best. Mention your retention rate in your pitch.
tips.twitch_sub: Don't undervalue live reads. Your audience is with you in real time, unlike scrollers.
tips.linkedin_b2b: B2B/Tech sponsors pay significantly more. Focus on decision-maker value, not just views.
tips.high_eng: Your engagement is stellar (>5%). Use this as your main leverage to demand higher rates.
tips.growth: You're consistent! Brands love reliability. Mention your posting streak.
tips.gap_close: You're beating the market average! Consider raising your base rates soon.
tips.email: Always move the conversation from DM to Email. It signals professionalism.
tips.contract: Never start work without a signed contract and a 50% deposit.
tips.tax: Remember to set aside ~30% of this income for taxes.
tips.portfolio: Update your Media Kit after every successful campaign with new case study numbers.
tips.followup: The money is in the follow-up. 60% of deals close after the 3rd email.

WAY_TOO_LOW: This offer is significantly below market rate. The brand is likely testing how much they can save.
At this price point, you'd be undervaluing your audience significantly.
This is a classic lowball offer. Professional creators typically reject offers below 50%.
TOO_LOW: There's definitely room for negotiation here. Counter 30-40% higher.
This offer shows interest but doesn't reflect your true value.
Most creators accept offers in this range too quickly. Negotiate!
ACCEPTABLE: This is a reasonable starting point. There's likely still 10-20% more on the table.
The offer is close to fair value. Consider negotiating for additional perks.
Not bad, but not great either. Worth accepting if you like the brand.
GOOD: Great offer! This brand clearly values your content.
This is at or above market rate. Solid deal to take.
Excellent position. You might even ask for extras like usage rights limitations.

undercharge.title: Why Most Creators Undercharge
undercharge.paragraph: Without market data, creators rely on guesswork. They either accept the first offer (usually too low) or make up a number and hope for the best. Brands know this — and take advantage of it.
undercharge.cta: Don't be one of them → Check your rate

faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.a1: Our rates are based on industry CPM data across niches, adjusted for audience size, engagement, content type, sponsor size, and audience location. It's the same data agencies use.
faq.a2: Free calculations are not stored. Pro users can optionally save calculations to track their rate over time.
faq.q3: What's the difference between Free and Pro?
faq.a3: Free shows you if an offer is fair or not (verdict). Pro shows you the exact dollar amount you should charge, plus negotiation tips and tools.
faq.a4: A startup offering $500 has different budget constraints than Nike offering $500. We factor this into our analysis.
faq.a5: Advertisers pay based on purchasing power. A US viewer is worth ~5x more to brands than a viewer in Southeast Asia.

meta.title: Manifesto for fair creator compensation | WMR
meta.description: Our manifesto: end information asymmetry between creators and brands. Objective data, fair pay, secure contracts. Your data stays confidential.

hero.subtitle: For too long, content creators have negotiated in the dark against data-armed brands. We're rebalancing the scales.

mission.paragraph: Our mission is simple: end information asymmetry and give creators the same data tools as agencies. Not to fuel distrust, but to build equitable partnerships where your audience, your niche, and your engagement are valued fairly.

comparison.old_2_text: you lower your rates for fear of losing the deal.
comparison.old_3_text: vague agreements, no solid PDF contract to protect you.
comparison.wmr_1_text: rate ranges based on the reality of your niche.
comparison.wmr_2_text: mathematical certainty of your audience's value.
comparison.wmr_3_text: instant compliant contract generation to lock in your revenue.

methodology.title: No magic—just math
methodology.paragraph: Our estimates don't come out of a hat. Our algorithm is transparent: it combines your audience size, real engagement rate, your region's purchasing power, and the type of company approaching you. Result? An objective, defensible price range ready to send by email.

security.title: Your data is your shield, not our product
security.paragraph: We only store what's needed to run your tools. Your revenue history and PDF contracts are secured and encrypted. We pledge never to sell your financial data to third-party agencies or use it to profile creators for brands.

cta.title: Ready to discover your true value?
cta.paragraph: Join creators who use data to never undersell their work again. Your first offer evaluation is 100% free.

instagram.title: Instagram Sponsorship Calculator
instagram.subtitle: Calculate your Instagram influencer rate in seconds.

content.pricing_title: How Much Should Instagram Influencers Charge?
content.pricing_desc_1: Pricing Instagram sponsorships is more complex than other platforms because of the variety of content types. Unlike YouTube where there's primarily video content, Instagram influencers can offer posts, Reels, Stories, carousels, and longer-form video. Each format has different reach potential, lifespan, and value to brands.
content.pricing_desc_2: The most common mistake Instagram influencers make is charging the same rate for all content types. A permanent feed post should cost more than a 24-hour Story, and a Reel with algorithm boost potential should command premium pricing. This calculator takes all these factors into account.
content.types_intro: Understanding the difference between Posts, Reels, and Stories is crucial for pricing:
content.types_posts_desc: Permanent content on your feed that becomes part of your portfolio, gets discovered through hashtags and Explore, and continues generating value long after posting. Brands pay premium for this permanence.
content.types_reels_desc: Short-form video with massive reach potential. Instagram's algorithm heavily favors Reels, often showing them to 5–10x more people than static posts. Because of this, Reels typically command 20–30% higher rates than static posts.
content.types_stories_desc: 24-hour ephemeral content. While Stories have lower rates due to their temporary nature, they're valuable for time-sensitive campaigns, swipe-up links, and urgency plays. They're often bundled with posts at a discount.
content.rates_title: Instagram Sponsorship Rates by Follower Count (2025)
content.rates_intro: Here are typical rate ranges for Instagram sponsorships based on follower count. These are baseline rates for mid-tier engagement (3–5%) in general lifestyle/entertainment niches. High-engagement accounts (8%+) or premium niches (finance, tech, health) can charge 50–100% more.
content.rates_note_text: These rates assume average engagement (3–5%) and general lifestyle/entertainment niches. Premium niches, high engagement, or exclusive partnerships can command significantly higher rates.
content.value_title: Posts vs Reels vs Stories: Understanding the Value
content.value_intro: Not all Instagram content is created equal. Here's why pricing varies by format:
content.value_posts_desc_1: Static posts (photos or carousels) are permanent fixtures on your profile. They stay visible, continue generating impressions, saves, and shares, and become part of your visual brand.
content.value_posts_desc_2: Because of this permanence and discoverability, feed posts command the baseline sponsorship rate. This is what brands usually mean when they ask "What's your rate for a post?"
content.value_reels_desc_1: Instagram Reels get significantly more reach than static posts due to algorithmic promotion and viral potential.
content.value_reels_desc_2: Most influencers charge 20–30% more for Reels than static posts, and sometimes more if the Reel requires complex video production, trending audio research, or detailed creative direction.
content.value_stories_desc_1: Stories disappear after 24 hours, which is why they're priced lower than posts and Reels.
content.value_stories_desc_2: Stories are typically 30–50% of your post rate but often bundled in packages (for example, "1 post + 3 Stories"). Swipe-up or link features can justify slightly higher Story rates.
content.factors_title: Factors That Affect Your Instagram Rate
content.factors_intro: Beyond follower count and content type, several factors influence how much you should charge:
content.factors_engagement_desc_1: Engagement matters more than follower count. A 20K account with 8% engagement is worth more than a 100K account with 2% engagement because brands care about interaction, not vanity metrics.
content.factors_engagement_benchmarks_low: Below 2% – Low (consider this a red flag).
content.factors_niche_desc: Some niches command premium rates because their audiences have higher purchasing power or because competition for influencers is fierce:
content.factors_niche_premium: Premium niches (charge 2–3x): Finance, investing, tech, business, health, real estate.
content.factors_niche_mid: Mid-tier niches (charge ~1.5x): Fashion, beauty, fitness, travel, food.
content.factors_niche_standard: Standard niches (baseline): Lifestyle, entertainment, comedy, general content.
content.factors_demo_desc_1: Where your audience is located dramatically affects your value to brands:
content.factors_demo_highest: US/UK/Canada/Australia (highest): Premium purchasing power and most brand budgets.
content.factors_demo_high: Western Europe (high): Strong markets, slightly below English-speaking countries.
content.factors_demo_medium: Latin America / Eastern Europe (medium): Growing markets with lower average budgets.
content.factors_demo_lower: India / Southeast Asia (lower): Massive scale but lower purchasing power.
content.factors_demo_warning: If 80% of your audience is in lower-CPM regions, you can't realistically charge US rates. Be transparent about your demographics in negotiations.
content.factors_quality_list1: Professional photography/videography instead of blurry smartphone photos.
content.factors_quality_list2: Consistent aesthetic, cohesive grid, and recognizable visual style.
content.factors_quality_list3: Strong captions, storytelling, and clear brand integration.
content.factors_quality_list4: Advanced editing (color grading, transitions, effects, sound design).
content.factors_fit_desc: How well a brand aligns with your content also affects pricing:
content.factors_fit_perfect: Perfect fit: Charge full rate or even premium if you'd use the product anyway.
content.factors_fit_stretch: Stretch fit: Charge more to compensate for potential audience skepticism.
content.factors_fit_offbrand: Off-brand: Charge significantly more or decline to protect your reputation.
content.faq_engagement_title: How do I calculate my engagement rate?
content.faq_engagement_example: For example, if you have 50,000 followers and your posts typically get 2,000 likes + 200 comments, your engagement rate is 4.4%. Calculate this over your last 10 posts and average it for accuracy.
content.faq_engagement_note: Instagram Insights also shows reach and impressions, but likes + comments is still the industry-standard metric most brands look at.
content.faq_campaign_title: Should I charge per post or per campaign?
content.faq_campaign_intro: It depends on the scope of work:
content.faq_campaign_per_post: Per post: Best for one-off collaborations or testing new brand relationships. Clear pricing and no long-term commitment.
content.faq_campaign_per_campaign: Per campaign (package deals): Best for ongoing partnerships. Offer bundles like "1 Reel + 2 Posts + 5 Stories" at a 15–20% discount versus buying each placement separately.
content.faq_campaign_example: Example: Instead of charging $1,000 per post × 3 = $3,000, offer a 3-post campaign for $2,500. You secure a larger contract and the brand feels they're getting better value.
content.faq_affiliate_title: What about affiliate links vs flat fee?
content.faq_affiliate_intro: Both flat fees and affiliate models have pros and cons:
content.faq_affiliate_flat_1: Predictable income — you know exactly what you'll earn.
content.faq_affiliate_flat_2: No performance risk — you get paid regardless of sales.
content.faq_affiliate_flat_3: Faster payment terms — usually upfront or upon posting.
content.faq_affiliate_flat_4: Preferred for brand deals — most sponsors are set up for this model.
content.faq_affiliate_perf_strong: Affiliate/commission (can be lucrative in some cases):
content.faq_affiliate_perf_1: Unlimited upside if the product converts well.
content.faq_affiliate_perf_2: Potential for ongoing, passive income after the post goes live.
content.faq_affiliate_perf_3: Works well for high-ticket items where a few sales pay a lot.
content.faq_affiliate_perf_4: High risk — if no one buys, you earn nothing.
content.faq_affiliate_hybrid: Hybrid approach (best of both worlds): Negotiate a smaller flat fee plus commission, for example: "$500 guaranteed + 10% of sales." This protects your downside while keeping upside potential.
content.faq_negotiate_title: How do I negotiate higher Instagram rates?
content.faq_negotiate_intro: If a brand's offer is below your rate card:
content.faq_negotiate_step1: Show your data — share engagement rate, audience demographics, and past campaign results.
content.faq_negotiate_step2: Reference market rates — use phrases like "Based on industry standards for my follower count and engagement…".
content.faq_negotiate_step3: Offer alternatives — for example: "I can do $X for a Reel, or $Y for a static post."
content.faq_negotiate_step4: Bundle for discounts — "My single post is $X, but I can do 3 posts for $Y."
content.faq_negotiate_step5: Add value — include Stories, Reels, or usage rights to justify your rate.
content.faq_negotiate_closing: Never accept the first offer without negotiation. Most brands expect a counter and have more budget than they initially reveal.
content.cta_desc_1: The free calculator at the top of this page evaluates any Instagram brand offer you receive and tells you if it's fair, too low, or way too low based on your specific metrics.
content.cta_desc_2_before_link: For Pro members, it also shows your exact recommended rate range (X–Y) so you know exactly what number to counter with.

youtube.title: YouTube Sponsorship Calculator
youtube.subtitle: Calculate your fair YouTube sponsorship rate in 30 seconds. Know if brands are lowballing you.

content.pricing_title: How to Price Your YouTube Sponsorships
content.pricing_desc: Pricing YouTube sponsorships is one of the most challenging aspects of being a content creator. Without market data, most YouTubers either charge too little (leaving money on the table) or charge too much (losing deals). This calculator solves that problem.
content.factors_title: What Factors Affect YouTube Sponsorship Rates?
content.factors_intro: YouTube sponsorship rates aren't one-size-fits-all. Here are the key factors that determine your fair market rate:
content.factors_subs_desc: More subscribers = higher base rate, but with diminishing returns.
content.factors_views_desc: The most important metric. Views = eyeballs on the brand.
content.factors_engagement_desc: High engagement (8%+) can increase your rate by 50%.
content.factors_niche_desc: Finance/Tech niches command 3-5x higher rates than gaming/entertainment.
content.factors_location_desc: US viewers are worth around 5x more than viewers in Southeast Asia.
content.factors_type_desc: Dedicated videos pay roughly 2.5x more than quick mentions.
content.factors_company_desc: Enterprise brands often pay 50% more than startups.
content.benchmarks_intro: Here are typical CPM rates (cost per 1,000 views) by niche for YouTube sponsorships:
content.benchmarks_note: These are base rates. Your actual rate will be higher or lower depending on the other factors mentioned above.
content.how_step1: Select YouTube as your platform (pre-selected on this page).
content.how_step2: Choose your content niche (this has the biggest impact on CPM).
content.how_step3: Enter your subscriber count and average views.
content.how_step4: Calculate your engagement rate: (likes + comments) / views × 100.
content.how_step5: Select the type of content (mention, integration, or dedicated video).
content.how_step6: Choose the sponsor's company size (affects budget expectations).
content.how_step9: Get your verdict: Is it fair, too low, or way too low?
content.mistakes_1_desc: "I have 100K subscribers, so I should charge $X" is wrong. Views matter 10x more than subscriber count. A channel with 50K subs but 50K average views is worth more than a channel with 200K subs but 10K average views.
content.mistakes_2_desc: 87% of creators accept the first offer without negotiating. Brands expect you to counter. The first offer is often 30–50% below their maximum budget.
content.mistakes_3_desc: If 80% of your audience is in India or Southeast Asia, you can't charge US rates. Brands pay based on purchasing power. This calculator adjusts for that.
content.mistakes_4_desc: Two channels with the same views but different engagement rates should charge differently. High engagement (8%+) proves your audience is loyal and actually watches your content.
content.lowballed_intro: If this calculator shows you're being offered 50% or less of your fair market value, here's what to do:
content.lowballed_step1_desc: Even if you need the money, always counter first.
content.lowballed_step2_desc: Share your analytics: views, engagement rate, and audience demographics.
content.lowballed_step3_desc: Use lines like "Based on industry CPM data for my niche…" to justify your rate.
content.lowballed_step4_desc: For example: "I can do $X for a mention, or $Y for a dedicated video."
content.lowballed_step5_desc: Bad deals hurt your long-term earning potential. Sometimes saying no is the best move.
content.accept_lower_intro: There are times when accepting below-market rates makes sense:
content.accept_lower_reason1_desc: If it's your dream brand, strategic exposure might be worth a discount.
content.accept_lower_reason2_desc: Lower rate per video but a guaranteed 6–12 month deal.
content.accept_lower_reason3_desc: You might accept slightly less to build proof of concept for future sponsors.
content.accept_lower_reason4_desc: If the free product or service is worth $1,000+ and truly useful to you.
content.accept_lower_warning: However, even in these cases, avoid going below 70% of your market rate. You're setting a precedent for future negotiations.
content.pro_title: Upgrade to Pro for Your Exact Rate
content.pro_intro_before_strong: The free calculator tells you if an offer is fair or not.
content.pro_intro_strong: Pro shows you your exact dollar amount (X–Y range) plus:
content.pro_benefit1: Detailed breakdown of how we calculated your rate.
content.pro_benefit2: Negotiation email templates to counter lowball offers.
content.pro_benefit3: Media kit generator so you look professional.
content.pro_benefit4: Track your rate growth and deal history over time.
content.pro_closing_strong: Just one better-negotiated deal pays for years of Pro.
content.faq_q1_desc: Very accurate. We use real CPM data from industry reports, adjusted for the key factors that affect sponsorship rates. It's the same methodology agencies use.
content.faq_q2_title: Should I charge per view or per video?
content.faq_q2_desc: Always per video (or per post). “Pay per view” deals are almost always bad for creators because you take on all the risk. Charge based on your average views, not actual performance.
content.faq_q3_title: What if my channel is growing fast?
content.faq_q3_desc: Renegotiate every 3–6 months, or include performance clauses: “If this video hits 100K views in 30 days, the rate increases by 30%.”
content.faq_q4_title: Do I need a media kit?
content.faq_q4_desc: For deals over $1,000, yes. It shows you're professional and makes it easier for brands to say yes. Pro members get access to our media kit generator.

tiktok.title: TikTok Sponsorship Calculator
tiktok.subtitle: Know your worth before your next TikTok brand deal

content.pricing_title: How Much Do TikTokers Charge for Sponsorships?
content.pricing_desc_1: TikTok sponsorship pricing is unique compared to other platforms because of the platform's viral nature and unpredictable algorithm. Unlike YouTube where views are relatively consistent, or Instagram where engagement rates are stable, TikTok views can fluctuate wildly from video to video.
content.pricing_desc_2_before_strong: One video might get 5,000 views while the next explodes to 500,000 views with the same follower count. This volatility makes pricing challenging. The key is to use your
content.pricing_desc_2_strong: average views over the last 10 videos
content.pricing_desc_2_after_strong: , not your best or worst performing video.
content.pricing_desc_3: TikTok creators typically charge based on their consistent average performance, not their viral outliers. Brands understand this and will ask for your metrics over time, not just your top video.
content.rates_title: TikTok Sponsorship Rates by Follower Count (2025)
content.rates_intro: Here are baseline rates for TikTok sponsorships. These assume average engagement (5–10%) and general entertainment/lifestyle content. High-engagement accounts (15%+) or premium niches can charge significantly more.
content.rates_note_before_em: These rates are based on your
content.rates_note_after_em: views, not your highest performing video. Always calculate your average views from your last 10 videos for accurate pricing.
content.fund_title: TikTok Creator Fund vs Sponsorships: The Reality Check
content.fund_intro: Many new TikTok creators rely on the Creator Fund for income. This is a mistake. Here's why:
content.fund_earnings_closing: Even viral videos barely pay enough for groceries. A video with 1 million views might earn you $30.
content.sponsor_earnings_intro_after_strong: (or more for premium niches). Same math:
content.sponsor_earnings_closing_before_strong: A sponsored video with 100,000 views can earn
content.bottom_line_para: Don't optimize for Creator Fund payments. Optimize for building an audience that brands want to reach. One $2,000 sponsorship is worth 50,000,000 views on the Creator Fund. Focus on brand deals, not pennies from the platform.
content.why_different_title: Why TikTok Rates Are Different from Other Platforms
content.why_different_intro: TikTok sponsorships operate differently than YouTube or Instagram for several reasons:
content.viral_intro: TikTok's algorithm can make any video go viral, regardless of follower count. This means:
content.viral_upside_desc: A 10K follower account can get 1M views and command higher rates
content.viral_downside_desc: Views are unpredictable, making pricing harder
content.viral_solution_desc: Always price based on average views, not viral potential
content.viral_closing: Brands know that TikTok views fluctuate. They'll look at your average performance, not your one viral hit from 6 months ago.
content.demographics_intro: TikTok's audience skews younger (Gen Z and young Millennials), which affects pricing:
content.demo_lower_desc: Younger audiences have less disposable income
content.demo_niche_desc: Finance/business TikTok commands 3–5x higher rates than dance/comedy
content.demo_brand_desc: Student-focused brands pay less than luxury brands
content.demographics_closing: If your content targets teens, expect lower rates than business/finance content targeting working professionals.
content.production_intro: TikTok videos are typically 15–60 seconds, compared to:
content.production_li_yt: YouTube videos: 8–20 minutes (much more production time)
content.production_li_ig: Instagram posts: Professional photos/editing (hours of work)
content.production_li_tt: TikTok: Quick, authentic, less editing (minutes to hours)
content.production_closing_before_strong: Shorter production time means brands sometimes expect lower rates. However,
content.production_closing_strong: your rate should be based on value delivered
content.production_closing_after_strong: (reach, engagement, conversions), not time spent. Don't undercharge just because it's "quick content."
content.algorithm_intro: Unlike Instagram where your followers see your content, or YouTube where subscribers are notified, TikTok's For You Page algorithm is chaotic:
content.algorithm_li_1: Videos don't show to all your followers
content.algorithm_li_3: The next video might get 200,000 views
content.algorithm_closing_strong: average views matter more than follower count
content.algorithm_closing_after_strong: on TikTok. A creator with 500K followers averaging 20K views is worth less than a creator with 50K followers averaging 50K views.
content.how_calc_title: How to Calculate Your Average Views
content.how_calc_intro: To price your TikTok sponsorships accurately, follow this process:
content.how_calc_step_1: Go to your TikTok profile and open your last 10 videos
content.how_calc_step_2: Write down the view count for each
content.how_calc_example_intro: Example: If your last 10 videos got 5K, 50K, 8K, 100K, 12K, 15K, 200K, 9K, 11K, 40K views:
content.how_calc_honest: Use this 45K number for pricing, not the 200K outlier. Brands will check this themselves, so being honest protects your reputation.
content.faq_per_video_title: Should I charge per video or per view?
content.faq_per_video_intro_strong: Always charge per video with a minimum view guarantee
content.faq_per_video_recommended_li_1: Predictable income – You know what you'll earn upfront
content.faq_per_video_recommended_li_2: No algorithm risk – If the video flops, you still get paid
content.faq_per_video_recommended_li_3: Industry standard – Most brands prefer flat fees
content.faq_per_video_recommended_li_4: Easier contracts – Simple pricing, quick payments
content.faq_per_video_risky_li_1: Algorithm dependent – TikTok decides if you get paid well
content.faq_per_video_risky_li_2: Delayed payment – Have to wait for views to accumulate
content.faq_per_video_risky_li_3: Tracking issues – Disputes over view counts
content.faq_per_video_hybrid_before_strong: Hybrid approach: Some creators negotiate "$2,000 flat fee + $10 per 1,000 views over 100K views."
content.faq_per_video_hybrid_strong: This protects your baseline while giving upside if the video goes viral.
content.faq_shop_intro: TikTok Shop (affiliate commission on product sales) can be lucrative for product-focused creators, but has limitations:
content.faq_shop_pros_li_1: Passive income potential – Earn on every sale
content.faq_shop_pros_li_3: Good for product reviews – Natural fit
content.faq_shop_pros_li_4: Compound over time – Multiple videos can drive sales
content.faq_shop_cons_li_1: No guaranteed income – You earn nothing if no one buys
content.faq_shop_cons_li_4: Audience fatigue – Too many affiliate videos hurt engagement
content.faq_shop_best_text: For new brand relationships, negotiate a flat fee. Once you've proven you can drive sales, then discuss commission-based deals or hybrid models. Don't work for free hoping for commissions.
content.faq_viral_title: How do I handle viral videos? Should I charge more?
content.faq_viral_intro: You can't predict viral videos, so negotiate terms upfront that protect both parties:
content.faq_viral_usage_li_1: "Brand can use video in ads for 30 days included in base rate"
content.faq_viral_usage_li_2: "Extended usage rights (60–90 days) cost an additional 50%"
content.faq_viral_usage_li_3: "If video exceeds 1M views, brand pays $X bonus"
content.faq_viral_bonus_li_2: Bonus: +$1,000 if video reaches 500K views in 7 days
content.faq_viral_bonus_li_3: Bonus: +$2,000 if video reaches 1M views in 30 days
content.faq_viral_closing: This way, if the video goes viral, you're compensated fairly. If it doesn't, you still got paid your base rate. Both sides win.
content.faq_viral_dont_after_strong: Come back to a brand after a video goes viral asking for more money. That wasn't in the contract and damages the relationship. Negotiate bonuses upfront instead.
content.compare_title: TikTok vs Other Platforms: Which Pays More?
content.compare_yt_desc: $20–$50 per 1K views (highest due to longer watch time)
content.compare_advantage_after_strong: . A TikTok video can reach 10x more people than an Instagram post with the same follower count. So while the CPM is lower, the total earnings can be higher due to volume.
content.cta_desc_1: The free calculator at the top of this page will evaluate any TikTok sponsorship offer based on your followers, average views, engagement rate, and niche. It tells you if the brand's offer is fair, too low, or way too low.
content.cta_desc_2_before_link: Pro members get the exact dollar range ($X – $Y) they should charge, plus negotiation scripts and performance bonus templates.

twitch.title: Twitch Sponsorship Calculator
twitch.subtitle: Calculate your Twitch stream sponsorship rate

content.pricing_title: How Much Do Twitch Streamers Charge for Sponsorships?
content.pricing_intro_1: Twitch sponsorships work fundamentally different from YouTube, Instagram, or TikTok deals. While other platforms rely on recorded content that accumulates views over time, Twitch is all about live interaction. This changes everything about how you should price your sponsorships.
content.pricing_intro_2_before_strong: The key metric for Twitch isn't your follower count—it's your
content.pricing_intro_2_after_strong: (CCV). A streamer with 100K followers but only 200 concurrent viewers is worth less to brands than a streamer with 20K followers and 1,000 concurrent viewers. Why? Because concurrent viewers represent your actual engaged audience in real-time.
content.rates_benchmarks_title: Twitch Sponsorship Rate Benchmarks by Average Concurrent Viewers
content.rates_benchmarks_intro: Here's what Twitch streamers typically charge based on their average concurrent viewership:
content.rates_note_before_em: Note: These rates are for a full sponsored stream (2-4 hours). Different sponsorship types
content.types_title: Types of Twitch Sponsorships and Their Pricing
content.types_intro: Not all Twitch sponsorships are created equal. Here are the most common types and how they affect your pricing:
content.type_mention_desc: A brief shoutout during your stream—thanking the sponsor, showing their logo, or reading a prepared message. This is the least intrusive format.
content.type_mention_example: If your base rate is $1,000, charge $300-$500
content.type_segment_desc: A focused segment where you try the product, demonstrate the service, or play a sponsored game. This involves gameplay, review, or hands-on demonstration.
content.type_segment_example: If your base rate is $1,000, charge $1,000
content.type_segment_best: Gaming sponsors, hardware reviews, software demos
content.type_full_desc: An entire stream dedicated to the sponsor. You play their game, use their product throughout, or focus your content around their brand. This is the most immersive format.
content.type_full_example: If your base rate is $1,000, charge $2,000-$3,000
content.type_multi_desc: A package deal where you stream sponsored content across multiple sessions (e.g., 4 streams over a month). Brands love this for sustained exposure.
content.type_multi_example: If your base rate is $1,000, charge $3,500-$4,000 for 4 streams
content.why_title: Why Twitch Rates Are Different from YouTube
content.why_intro: If you're coming from YouTube or other platforms, Twitch sponsorship pricing might feel confusing. Here's why the rates work differently:
content.why_live_para: When you mention a sponsor on a live stream, your audience sees your genuine, unedited reaction. You can't do multiple takes or heavily script it. This authenticity is valuable—but also riskier for brands (you might say the wrong thing). The live format creates trust but limits scale.
content.why_replay_title: 2. No Replay Value = Lower Total Reach
content.why_replay_para: A YouTube video can accumulate 100K views over months. A Twitch stream reaches your concurrent viewers and that's it. VODs get minimal views (usually 5-10% of live viewership). This means lower total impressions, which justifies lower CPM rates compared to YouTube.
content.why_followers_para: You might have 50K followers, but if you average 200 concurrent viewers, brands will pay for the 200—not the 50K. Many Twitch followers are inactive or followed you years ago. Concurrent viewership is the only metric that matters.
content.why_subs_title: 4. Subs and Donations Signal Real Value
content.why_subs_para: Unlike other platforms, Twitch has built-in monetization (subs, bits, donations). If you have a high subscriber count or frequent donations, it proves your audience doesn't just watch—they spend money. This is gold for sponsors and can justify 20-40% higher rates.
content.factors_title: Factors That Increase Your Twitch Sponsorship Rate
content.factors_niche_intro: Not all Twitch categories are created equal when it comes to sponsorship value:
content.factors_niche_li_1_desc: Highest CPM ($20-40). Tech brands have big budgets.
content.factors_niche_li_6_desc: Lower CPM ($8-15). Less engaged audience for products.
content.factors_chat_para: Active chat matters. If your 500 viewers are constantly chatting, asking questions, and engaging with you, that's worth more than 1,000 silent viewers. Brands can see chat activity and know a lively chat means their message will get noticed and discussed.
content.factors_subs_para: A high subscriber count (paid subs, not followers) proves your audience is willing to spend money. If you have 500 concurrent viewers and 200 subscribers, that's a 40% sub rate—exceptional. This can add 30-50% to your base rate.
content.factors_demo_intro: Brands care about who watches you:
content.factors_demo_li_1_desc: 18-34 male demographic is most valuable (disposable income, tech-savvy)
content.factors_demo_li_2_desc: US/UK/Canada viewers worth 3-5x more than global average
content.factors_demo_li_3_desc: PC gamers spend more than console gamers (better demographics)
content.factors_exclusivity_para: Want to charge more? Offer exclusivity. If a gaming chair brand wants you to never show competing chairs for 30 days, charge 30-50% more. Long-term deals (3-6 months) should also command premium pricing—you're guaranteeing sustained exposure.
content.faq_calc_title: How do I calculate my Twitch sponsorship rate?
content.faq_calc_para_1_before_strong: Start with your average concurrent viewers (CCV). A simple formula is:
content.faq_calc_para_1_after_strong: . So if you average 500 viewers, your base rate is $500-$1,000 per sponsored stream. Then adjust based on niche, engagement, and sponsorship type.
content.faq_calc_para_2: For more accuracy, use our calculator above. It factors in your hours streamed, follower count, content type, and audience location to give you a precise rate.
content.faq_per_hour_title: Should I charge per hour or per stream?
content.faq_per_hour_para_1_after_strong: is the industry standard. You quote a flat rate for a sponsored stream (typically 2-4 hours). Charging per hour can backfire—if you run long, brands might complain about cost; if you run short, you lose money. Flat rate per stream protects both parties.
content.faq_per_hour_para_2: Exception: If a brand wants you to stream their game for 8+ hours, negotiate hourly or break it into two separate streams.
content.faq_subs_title: Do subscribers matter more than viewers?
content.faq_subs_para_1_strong: Subscribers are a quality signal, but viewers are the quantity.
content.faq_subs_para_1_after_strong: Brands pay for reach (concurrent viewers), but a high subscriber-to-viewer ratio proves engagement and loyalty. A streamer with 1,000 viewers and 300 subs is more valuable than one with 1,000 viewers and 50 subs—the first audience is clearly more invested.
content.faq_subs_para_2: Use your sub count to negotiate up. "I average 500 viewers with a 25% sub rate" sounds much better than just "I average 500 viewers."
content.faq_small_title: How much do small Twitch streamers make from sponsors?
content.faq_small_para_1: Small streamers (50-200 average viewers) typically make $200-$1,000 per sponsored stream. This might not sound like much, but if you stream 3-4 times per week, landing 1-2 sponsors per month can add $400-$2,000 to your income—a meaningful boost.
content.faq_small_para_2: The key is consistency. Brands want reliable streamers. If you stream regularly at the same times and maintain steady viewership, you're more attractive to sponsors than someone with higher but inconsistent numbers.
content.faq_sponsor_vs_title: What's the difference between a sponsor and an affiliate deal?
content.faq_sponsor_para: Flat fee paid upfront or upon completion. You get $X to promote their product during your stream. Simple, predictable income.
content.faq_affiliate_para: Performance-based. You get a commission (usually 5-20%) when viewers use your code or link to buy. Income varies—could be $0 or $5,000 depending on conversions.
content.faq_hybrid_para: Many streamers negotiate hybrid deals: "I'll do a sponsored segment for $500 + 10% commission on sales." This gives you guaranteed money plus upside if the product resonates with your audience.
content.faq_find_title: How do I find sponsors for my Twitch channel?
content.faq_find_intro: Here are the most effective strategies:
content.faq_find_li_1_desc: PowerSpike, Ader, Matchmade connect streamers with sponsors
content.faq_find_li_2_desc: GFuel, DXRacer, and other gaming brands have streamer programs
content.faq_find_li_3_desc: Email brands you genuinely use. "I stream to 300 viewers in the FPS category..."
content.faq_find_li_4_desc: They often share sponsor contacts or introduce you
content.faq_find_li_5_desc: 1-page PDF with your stats, audience demos, past sponsors, and rates
content.faq_find_closing: Start with smaller brands. A local gaming cafe or indie game developer is more likely to say yes than Razer or Red Bull. Build your portfolio, then approach bigger sponsors.
content.mistakes_title: Common Mistakes Twitch Streamers Make with Sponsorships
content.mistake_ccv_title: 1. Quoting Follower Count Instead of Concurrent Viewers
content.mistake_ccv_para: "I have 20K followers, so I charge $X" is wrong. Brands will immediately ask for your average concurrent viewers, and if it's only 100, your 20K followers mean nothing. Always lead with CCV.
content.mistake_free_para: "We'll send you a free gaming chair" is not a sponsorship—it's exposure. A $300 chair is not worth a 3-hour sponsored stream. Accept free product only if: (a) you were going to buy it anyway, (b) it comes with cash, or (c) you're under 50 average viewers and building portfolio.
content.mistake_boundaries_para: Sponsors will ask for everything: stream their game for 6 hours, post clips on Twitter, make a YouTube video, wear their merch. Learn to say no or charge extra. Your contract should clearly state: "One 3-hour stream, period. Additional content requires separate negotiation."
content.mistake_untested_para: Your community trusts you. If you promote a scam VPN or sketchy crypto app for a quick $500, you'll lose that trust forever. Only promote products you've personally used or genuinely believe in. It's not worth the long-term damage.
content.cta_title: Ready to Calculate Your Twitch Sponsorship Rate?
content.cta_para_1: Use the calculator at the top of this page to get your personalized rate. Enter your average concurrent viewers, hours streamed per month, follower count, and other details. The calculator will give you a fair market rate based on real industry data.
content.cta_para_2_before_strong: Remember: your rate isn't set in stone. If a brand loves your content and has budget, they'll pay more. If they're a small indie dev, you might accept less for a product you're excited about.
content.cta_para_2_strong: Use the calculator as your starting point, then negotiate based on context.
content.next_steps_title: Next Steps: Using Your Rate in Negotiations
content.next_steps_li_1: Create a simple one-page media kit with your stats and pricing
content.next_steps_li_2: Join 2-3 influencer networks that work with Twitch streamers
content.next_steps_li_3: Reach out to 5-10 brands in your niche with personalized pitches
content.next_steps_li_4: When a brand makes an offer, compare it to your calculated rate
content.next_steps_li_5: If it's below 70% of your rate, counter with your number and justify it
content.next_steps_closing: Most importantly: don't undervalue yourself. Twitch streaming takes time, energy, and skill. Brands approach you because you've built something valuable. Charge accordingly.

podcast.title: Podcast Sponsorship Rate Calculator
podcast.subtitle: Calculate how much to charge for podcast ads

content.pricing_title: How Much Should Podcasters Charge for Sponsorships?
content.pricing_intro_1_before_strong: Podcast sponsorship pricing is fundamentally different from YouTube or Instagram because it's based on
content.pricing_intro_1_after_strong: , not followers or subscribers. A podcast with 10,000 downloads per episode can command higher rates than a YouTube channel with 100,000 subscribers if that channel only gets 5,000 views per video.
content.pricing_intro_2: Podcast listeners are also highly engaged. Unlike scrolling through Instagram or skipping YouTube ads, podcast listeners actively choose to tune in and often listen to entire episodes. This attention makes podcast sponsorships incredibly valuable to advertisers.
content.pricing_intro_3_before_strong: The standard metric for podcast pricing is
content.pricing_intro_3_after_strong: - the price per 1,000 downloads. Industry standard CPM ranges from $18-$50 depending on your niche, audience demographics, ad placement, and whether it's host-read or produced.
content.rates_intro: Here are current CPM rates and total episode rates based on average downloads per episode. These assume mid-roll, host-read ads in general interest podcasts. Premium niches (business, finance, tech) can command 50-100% higher rates.
content.rates_note_before_strong: Note: These rates assume mid-roll, host-read ads. Pre-roll and post-roll ads
content.rates_note_after_strong: , while premium niches (business, investing, health) can charge 50-100% more than these baseline rates.
content.placement_title: Pre-Roll vs Mid-Roll vs Post-Roll: Understanding Ad Placement
content.placement_intro: Where your ad appears in the episode dramatically affects pricing. Here's the breakdown:
content.preroll_desc: Pre-roll ads play before your episode content begins, typically 15-30 seconds.
content.preroll_pros: Listeners haven't skipped yet, easy to implement
content.preroll_cons: Often skipped by regular listeners, less integrated into content
content.preroll_best: Brand awareness campaigns, intro to new sponsors
content.preroll_closing: Pre-roll is the least expensive ad placement because listeners can easily skip ahead. Regular listeners know exactly how far to skip to get to the content.
content.midroll_desc: Mid-roll ads play in the middle of your episode, usually 60 seconds, seamlessly integrated into the content flow.
content.midroll_pros: Hard to skip, listeners are already engaged, feels natural
content.midroll_cons: Can disrupt flow if not done well, limited to 1-2 per episode
content.midroll_closing_before_strong: Mid-roll is the most valuable placement because listeners are already invested in the episode. By the time they reach the 20-30 minute mark, they're committed to finishing.
content.midroll_closing_strong: This is why mid-roll commands premium pricing.
content.postroll_desc: Post-roll ads play after your main content concludes, typically 15-30 seconds.
content.postroll_pros: Doesn't disrupt content, can be longer if needed
content.postroll_cons: Most listeners have dropped off by this point, lowest completion rate
content.postroll_best: Bonus sponsor mentions, thank-yous, low-priority placements
content.postroll_closing: Post-roll has the lowest completion rate because many listeners stop as soon as the main content ends. Only charge for post-roll if the brand specifically requests it or as a bonus add-on to mid-roll placements.
content.cpm_breakdown_intro: For a 10,000 download episode, here's what each placement is worth:
content.cpm_breakdown_closing_before_strong: As you can see, a single mid-roll ad is worth as much as pre-roll + post-roll combined.
content.cpm_breakdown_closing_strong: This is why most podcasters reserve mid-roll for their premium sponsors.
content.hostread_intro: Not all podcast ads are created equal. Host-read ads command 2-3x higher rates than produced ads. Here's why:
content.hostread_trust_para_1: When the host personally reads the ad in their own voice, it feels like a recommendation from a friend, not a commercial. Listeners trust the host and transfer that trust to the sponsor.
content.hostread_trust_para_2: A produced ad (pre-recorded by the brand) sounds like every other ad listeners hear on radio or TV. It's clearly advertising. A host-read ad sounds like the host genuinely uses and recommends the product.
content.hostread_conversion_para_1: Advertisers pay more for host-read ads because they convert better. Studies show host-read ads have 2-4x higher click-through rates and conversion rates compared to produced ads.
content.hostread_conversion_para_2: When Joe Rogan talks about Onnit supplements in his natural, conversational style, listeners are far more likely to try it than if a generic voice actor reads a script.
content.hostread_personal_para_1: Host-read ads can include personal stories, anecdotes, and natural transitions that make them feel like part of the episode rather than an interruption.
content.hostread_personal_para_2: Example: "Before we dive into today's topic, let me tell you about something I've been using every morning..." feels natural. A produced ad can't do this.
content.hostread_premium_closing_before_strong: Always position yourself as a "host-read only" podcaster.
content.hostread_premium_closing_strong: This protects your listener experience and commands higher rates.
content.hostread_premium_closing_after_strong: If a brand wants a produced ad, they can buy programmatic advertising elsewhere.
content.how_calc_title: How to Calculate Your Podcast Sponsorship Rate
content.how_calc_note_strong: average downloads from the last 5-10 episodes
content.how_calc_note_after_strong: for accurate pricing. Don't cherry-pick your best episode or include outliers.
content.faq_cpm_title: What's a good CPM for podcasts?
content.faq_cpm_li_1: $18-$25: Standard rate for general interest podcasts (comedy, entertainment, true crime)
content.faq_cpm_li_2: $25-$35: Above average for engaged audiences or specific niches (sports, parenting, education)
content.faq_cpm_li_3: $35-$50: Premium rates for business, finance, tech, health, marketing podcasts
content.faq_cpm_li_4: $50+: Elite rates for highly targeted B2B podcasts or celebrity-hosted shows
content.faq_cpm_closing: Your niche matters more in podcasting than any other platform. A business podcast with 2,000 downloads can charge more per download than a comedy podcast with 10,000 downloads because business listeners have higher purchasing power and lifetime value.
content.faq_network_title: Should I join a podcast network?
content.faq_network_intro: Podcast networks (like Wondery, Podcast One, or Midroll) can bring sponsors, but they take a cut. Here's the breakdown:
content.faq_network_join_pros: They handle sales, bring sponsors, provide production support, guarantee minimum rates
content.faq_network_join_cons: They take 30-50% of revenue, less control over sponsors, exclusive contracts
content.faq_network_join_best: Podcasters who don't want to sell or have under 5,000 downloads/episode
content.faq_network_diy_pros: Keep 100% of revenue, choose your sponsors, build direct relationships
content.faq_network_diy_cons: Have to do your own sales, invoicing, ad operations
content.faq_network_diy_best: Podcasters with 5,000+ downloads who can attract sponsors
content.faq_network_rec_text: Start DIY if you can. Join a network if you've been podcasting 6+ months with decent downloads but can't land sponsors yourself. Once you hit 10,000+ downloads, consider leaving the network and going DIY again to keep more revenue.
content.faq_prove_title: How do I prove my download numbers?
content.faq_prove_intro: Sponsors need verified download numbers before they'll pay. Here's how to prove your stats:
content.faq_prove_platform_li_1: Spotify for Podcasters (formerly Anchor): Free, provides analytics
content.faq_prove_platform_li_4: Podbean: Good for beginners, verified stats
content.faq_prove_avoid: Avoid self-hosted analytics or platforms without IAB certification. Brands don't trust them.
content.faq_prove_share_li_2: 30-day download numbers (many people listen weeks after release)
content.faq_prove_closing: Most hosting platforms provide a "media kit" export or analytics dashboard you can screenshot and share. Never lie about your numbers - sponsors will find out and blacklist you.
content.faq_per_episode_title: Should I charge per episode or per campaign?
content.faq_per_episode_para_1_text: Best for testing new sponsors or one-off collaborations. Clear, simple, easy to negotiate.
content.faq_per_episode_para_2_text: Better for ongoing partnerships. Offer package deals like "4 episodes for the price of 3" or "12-week campaign at 15% discount."
content.faq_per_episode_para_3: Brands prefer campaigns because advertising works through repetition. Listeners need to hear about a product 3-5 times before they take action. A single episode rarely converts well.
content.faq_per_episode_para_4_text: Start per-episode for new sponsors. Once they see results, pitch them on a multi-episode package for better rates and committed revenue.
content.cta_para_1: The free calculator at the top of this page will help you evaluate sponsorship offers based on your downloads per episode, ad placement, and niche. It shows you if the offered CPM is fair, too low, or way too low.
content.cta_para_2_before_link: Pro members get the exact CPM range they should charge ($X - $Y), plus negotiation scripts specific to podcasters and sample sponsor packages.

privacy.title: Privacy Policy
privacy.meta_description: WMR Privacy Policy - How we collect and use your data
privacy.section1_intro: We collect information you provide when using WMR:
privacy.section1_li1_after: — for account creation and authentication (via Supabase Auth)
privacy.section1_li2_after: — optional, stored in your profile (Supabase Auth user_metadata)
privacy.section1_li3_after: — optional, stored in your profile (Supabase Auth user_metadata)
privacy.section1_li4_after: — your calculations, preferences, and subscription status, to provide the service
privacy.section1_payment_mid: (e.g. card details) is collected and processed securely by
privacy.section1_payment_after: . We do not store your full credit card number on our servers.
privacy.section2_text: We use the collected data to provide and improve the Service (rate calculator, negotiation tools, media kit generation), to manage your account and subscription, to process billing via Stripe, and to send important account or security notices. We do not sell your personal data to third parties.
privacy.section3_before: Account and usage data are stored on
privacy.section3_after: (PostgreSQL database). Authentication is handled by Supabase Auth. Data is retained for as long as your account is active or as needed to provide the Service and comply with legal obligations.
privacy.section4_after: , necessary for session management and authentication (e.g. to keep you logged in). We do not use advertising or third-party tracking cookies for marketing purposes on the core Service.
privacy.section5_text: Depending on your location (e.g. GDPR in the EU, CCPA in California), you may have the right to access, correct, delete, or port your personal data, and to object to or restrict certain processing. To exercise these rights, contact us at the email below. You may also have the right to lodge a complaint with a supervisory authority.

terms.title: Terms of Service
terms.meta_description: WMR Terms of Service - Rate Calculator & Negotiation Tools
terms.section1_service_after: means WMR, including its rate calculator (free tier), negotiation tools, analytics, media kits, and any related features offered as a Software-as-a-Service (SaaS) platform for content creators and influencers.
terms.section1_user_after: means any person or entity accessing or using the Service.

terms.section2_text: You are responsible for maintaining the confidentiality of your account credentials and for all activity under your account. You must notify us immediately of any unauthorized use. WMR is not liable for any loss or damage arising from your failure to protect your account or from unauthorized access resulting from your negligence.
terms.section3_p1_after: . By subscribing, you agree to the pricing and billing terms displayed at the time of purchase. Fees are charged in advance (e.g. monthly or annually).
terms.section3_p1_no_refund_after: are offered for partial periods or unused portions of the Service, except where required by applicable law.
terms.section3_p2_strong: cancel your subscription at any time

seo_pricing.title: How Much Should You Charge for Sponsorships?
seo_pricing.subtitle: The complete guide to pricing brand deals in 2025
seo_pricing.meta_title: How Much to Charge for Sponsorships - Creator Pricing Guide 2025
seo_pricing.meta_description: Learn exactly how much to charge for sponsorships on YouTube, Instagram, TikTok, and podcasts. Free calculator + expert pricing guide.
seo_pricing.body_why_undercharge_p1: According to industry research, around 87% of creators undercharge for their first brand partnership. This isn’t a lack of professionalism – it’s a lack of market data to price confidently.
seo_pricing.body_why_undercharge_p2: Without clear benchmarks for what other creators with similar metrics charge, most people fall into one of these patterns:
seo_pricing.body_why_undercharge_li1_after: – many brands intentionally start low, expecting you to negotiate.
seo_pricing.body_why_undercharge_li2_after: – usually too low, driven by fear of scaring the brand away.
seo_pricing.body_why_undercharge_li3_after: – which hands all negotiating power to the brand.
seo_pricing.body_barriers_intro: Three main psychological barriers explain most of this undercharging:
seo_pricing.body_lack_data_p1: You can’t price what you can’t measure. Unlike traditional jobs with salary benchmarks and public data, creator sponsorship rates are rarely discussed openly. This information asymmetry heavily favors brands, who work with hundreds of creators and know exactly what market rates look like.
seo_pricing.body_fear_loss_p1: When a brand reaches out – especially for your first few partnerships – the fear of “messing it up” is huge. You think: “What if I ask for too much and they walk away?”. In reality, if a brand truly wants to work with you, they almost always have budget flexibility: the first offer is rarely their maximum.
seo_pricing.body_imposter_p1: Many creators think: “Who am I to charge $1,000? I’m not a big influencer.” Brands, however, are not paying for your ego – they’re paying for access to your audience. If you have 10,000 engaged followers in a high-value niche (B2B, finance, health, tech…), you deserve to be paid at market rate.
seo_pricing.body_rates_overview_p1: Here’s a quick overview of standard sponsorship rate ranges across major platforms. Click each platform-specific calculator for detailed breakdowns and a tailored estimate.
seo_pricing.body_rates_youtube_range: $20–$50 depending on niche and audience quality
seo_pricing.body_rates_instagram_range: $100–$1,000+ per 10k followers, depending on engagement rate
seo_pricing.body_rates_tiktok_range: $200–$1,000 per 10k followers, depending on viral potential
seo_pricing.body_rates_note: These are baseline ranges for general content. Premium niches (finance, tech, business, health) can justify 2–3x these rates. Use our platform-specific calculators for precise pricing.

help_bubble.free_p1: In free mode, you can add all your brands and their collaborations in the Compliance & Contracts tab. Each deal is counted to automatically calculate your total per brand and alert you when you approach or exceed the €1,000 legal threshold requiring a written contract.
help_bubble.free_p2: You can also generate a PDF contract based on French law to formalize a collaboration: in the free version, generation is limited to one download per month with a "Generated with WMR – Free version" watermark. The PRO subscription unlocks unlimited white-label export, no watermark, for all your partners.
help_bubble.free_legal_note: Contracts generated by the application are governed exclusively by French law and intended for collaborations under this jurisdiction.
help_bubble.pro_calc_1: The left panel lets you set parameters and generate new rate estimates in real time.
help_bubble.pro_calc_2: The right panel compiles your history with dynamic performance charts.
help_bubble.pro_calc_3: The dropdown at the top right adjusts the analysis period (from 30 days to full history).
help_bubble.pro_business_1: Enter your tax identity in the left column to be able to generate valid documents.
help_bubble.pro_business_2: Add your deals in the center: the algorithm calculates your 12-month totals and triggers a red alert when the €1,000 legal threshold is exceeded.
help_bubble.pro_business_3: Generate your PDF contracts by selecting the relevant deals and customizing your rights assignment clauses (duration, territory, supports).
help_bubble.pro_business_4: Legal note: Contracts generated by the application are governed exclusively by French law and intended for collaborations under this jurisdiction.
